overall_score_comment: A solid 4 out of 10 — like Tommy's financial planning skills.
the_roast:
Let me get this straight: we open with 'Once upon a time, not so long ago' like we're reading a bedtime story about economic depression. Tommy worked on the docks, union's on strike, and his brilliant solution is to... pawn his guitar? That's not 'living on a prayer,' that's living on weaponized optimism and a complete absence of a resume.

Meanwhile, Gina's out here 'working for her man' and 'bringing home her pay,' which sounds less like a love story and more like she's the only functioning adult in this relationship. She's pulling double shifts at the diner while Tommy's at home whispering 'someday' like it's a financial strategy. Newsflash: 'someday' doesn't pay the rent, and neither does a pawned guitar that 'used to make it talk.' What did it say, Tommy? 'Get a job'?

The chorus insists 'it doesn't make a difference if we make it or not' — which is exactly the kind of thing you say when you've given up on making it. 'We've got each other and that's a lot' is beautiful until the lights get shut off. And they're only 'halfway there'? Halfway to WHERE? Bankruptcy court? The chorus is basically Stockholm Syndrome set to a killer riff.

The bridge delivers the absolute gem: 'You live for the fight when it's all that you've got.' Brother, if fighting is ALL you've got, maybe update that LinkedIn profile. This isn't inspirational — it's a cry for help wrapped in denim and hairspray. The whole song is like a motivational poster written by someone who's never seen a motivational poster work.

hidden_meanings: This song is clearly a metaphor for trickle-down economics: everyone's waiting for something good to happen while pretending the current situation is sustainable. Tommy pawning his guitar represents giving up your dreams for immediate cash, which is exactly what Jon Bon Jovi DIDN'T do — making this the ultimate 'do as I say, not as I do' anthem.
final_verdict: This is poverty cosplay for the arena rock set — a anthem for people who confuse stubbornness with strength. It's the musical equivalent of putting 'live, laugh, love' on your eviction notice.
title: Livin' on a Prayer
